sentence-detokenized: The EU rejected Germany's call to boycott British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday it disagreed with German advice to consumers to stay away from British lamb until scientists can determine whether mad cow disease is transmitted to sheep.

Werner Zwingmann, Germany's representative on the European Union veterinary committee, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than Britain until scientific advice is clear.
"We do not support such a recommendation because we do not see any justification for it," said Nikolaus van der Pas, the Commission's chief spokesman, at a press briefing.
He said that more scientific studies should be carried out and that if it is found that action needs to be taken, this should be done by the European Union.

He said EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler's proposal last month to ban sheep brain, spleen and spinal cord from human and animal food chains was a highly specific and precautionary move to protect human health.
Fischler proposed EU-wide measures following reports from the UK and France showing that in laboratory conditions sheep can contract Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease.

However, Fischler agreed to revise his proposal after the EU's standing veterinary committee questioned whether national animal health authorities were justified in taking such action because there was only a slight risk to human health.
Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio had earlier accused Fischler at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers of causing unjustified alarm by making a "dangerous generalisation".
Only France and Britain supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU's scientific veterinary and multidisciplinary committees are expected to re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to contract scrapie, a brain wasting disease similar to BSE, which is believed to be passed to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers denied on Thursday that their sheep posed any danger to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to stay away from British lamb could affect consumers in Europe.
"What we need to be extremely cautious about is how other countries take Germany's lead," John Lloyd Jones, President of the National Farmers Union of Wales (NFU), told BBC radio.

Bonn has led efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence collapsed in March after a British report suggested that people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease by eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK last year, almost half of the total imports.
It brought in 4,275 tonnes of British mutton, accounting for about 10 per cent of total imports.
The rare Hendrix song draft sells for about $17,000.
A rare handwritten song outline by US guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold for nearly $17,000 on Thursday at an auction of some of the late musician's favourite items.
A restaurant in Florida paid 10,925 pounds ($16,935) for a draft of Hendrix's "Ain't no telling" written on stationery from a London hotel in late 1966.
In January 1967, at the end of his concert in Nottingham, England, he threw the paper into the audience and was retrieved by a fan.
Buyers also snapped up 16 other items auctioned by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, with whom he lived from 1966 to 1969.
Among them was a black lacquered and mother-of-pearl inlaid box used by Hendrix to store his medication, which was purchased by an anonymous Australian buyer for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere of the talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22

China accused Taipei on Thursday of disrupting the atmosphere necessary for the resumption of talks across the Taiwan Strait with Taiwan Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Ukraine this week, which angered Beijing.

Speaking just hours after Chinese state media said it was time to start political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters that "the atmosphere necessary for the start of talks has been spoilt by the Taiwan authorities. "
State media quoted Tang Shubei, China's top negotiator with Taipei, as telling a group from Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for both sides to start political talks...
This is to end the state of hostility," Tang was quoted as saying in Thursday's overseas edition of the People's Daily.

In an interview with Reuters Television, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen said he had read reports of Tang's comments but gave no details on why the negotiator thought the time was right for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed Taipei's efforts to gain greater international recognition, was infuriated by Taiwan Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine this week.
China says the time is right for Taiwan talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China said the time had come for political talks with Taiwan and the rival island should take practical steps towards that end.

Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Taiwan Cross-Straits Relations Association, said consultations should be held to determine the time and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency reported late Wednesday.
July car registrations in Germany increased by 14.2% yoy.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
First-time registrations of motor vehicles in Germany rose by 14.2 per cent in July this year compared to the previous year, the Federal Motor Vehicles Office reported on Thursday.
The Office reported that 356,725 new vehicles were registered in July 1996, including 304,850 passenger cars and 15,613 trucks.
These figures indicate an increase of 13.6 per cent for passenger cars and a decrease of 2.2 per cent for trucks compared to July 1995.
Motorcycle registrations increased by 32.7 percent in this period.
The federal office stated that the growth was partly due to an increase in the number of Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak.
Almost all German car manufacturers recorded an increase in registrations in this period.
Volkswagen AG won 77.719 registrations, slightly more than a quarter of the total.
Together with General Motors, Opel AG ranked second with 49,269 registrations, accounting for 16.4 per cent of the total.
Ford ranked third with 35,563 units or 11.7 per cent.
Only Seat and Porsche registered fewer registrations in July 1996 than in July last year.
Seat recorded 3,420 registrations compared to 5522 registrations in July of the previous year.
Porsche's registrations dropped from 643 to 554.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE THE PRIME MINISTER THE GREEN LIGHT FOR THE ELECTIONS.

Costas Skandalidis, Secretary General of the Socialist Party of Greece, told reporters that the party's executive board had given the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call for early elections.
Mr Skandalidis said that Prime Minister Kostas Simitis would make an official statement after the cabinet meeting on Thursday.
-- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens News Centre +301 3311812-4

Port conditions from Lloyds Shipping Intelligence Service --
LATTAKIA, 10 August - The waiting time in Latakia and Tartus is still 24 hours.
Israel underestimates the fear of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tension between the two countries looks like a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israeli ambassador to Washington conducted fruitless negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that Damascus wants to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that {(1)[MISC] Syria's priority} is still to negotiate.
The Syrians are confused, they are certainly nervous, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is essentially a storm in a teacup."
Rabinovich's term as ambassador is coming to an end.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a former Israeli ambassador to Egypt and politician from the right-wing Likud party.
On Wednesday, Israel sent a message to Syria through Washington that it is committed to peace and wants to start negotiations without preconditions.
However, he criticised Damascus for creating a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria on Wednesday accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently tested a missile.
He said the arms purchases were for defence purposes.

"The message we are sending to (Syrian President Hafez) Assad is that Israel is ready for peace talks at any time without preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israel Radio.
Since taking office in June, Israeli Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu's pledge to retain the Golan Heights, which Israel seized from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war, has escalated tensions.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks have been deadlocked over the Golan since 1991, despite the willingness of the previous government to make concessions on the Golan.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The sounds coming from Damascus are not good, they are bad.
Media...
is full of worrying statements and declarations...
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its captives."
"We expect Syria to respond to Israel's message to start peace talks if its face is turned towards peace, because this is our goal," he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
Wars are in nobody's interest. "
Israel's Channel Two television said Damascus had sent a "calming signal" to Israel.
No source is indicated for the report.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm this.
The television also said that Netanyahu had sent messages through Cairo, the United States and Moscow to reassure Syria.
Polish diplomat denies nurses trapped in Libya.

A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a Polish newspaper report published in Poland this week that Libya had denied exit visas to 100 Polish nurses who wanted to return home after working in the North African country.
"That's not true.

"To date, we are not aware of any nurses stranded in Libya or held against their will in Libya and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, Charge d'Affaires at the Polish Embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone.

Poland's Labour Ministry announced this week that it would send a team to Libya to investigate, while Awdankiewicz said the investigation was launched after some nurses complained about working conditions, including unpaid salaries.
He said that an estimated 800 Polish nurses were working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders met in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iranian exile group in Iraq pledged on Thursday support for Iranian Kurdish rebels who were attacked by Iranian troops deep inside Iraq last month.

Mujahid Khalq said in a statement that its leader Massoud Rajavi met with Hassan Rastegar, Secretary General of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran, in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed Iran's support for the Kurdish rebels.
"Rajavi emphasised that the Iranian Resistance will continue to stand side by side with Kurdish citizens and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan."
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "signalled a new level of co-operation between the Mujahedin Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
Iran intensively bombed targets in northern Iraq in July in order to pursue KDPI guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside the control of the Baghdad government.
The Kurdish areas of Iraq bordering Iran are under the control of Iraqi Kurdish Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK) guerrillas.
The two main Kurdish groups in Iraq, the PUK and the Iraqi Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), have controlled northern Iraq since the expulsion of Iraqi forces from Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Fighting between the two sides erupted over the weekend in the most serious clashes since a US-backed ceasefire last year.
Mujahid Khalq said that Iranian troops have been bombarding KDP positions in the Kasri area in Sulaymaniyah province near the Iranian border for the last two days.
It was stated that approximately 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey are carrying out air and ground attacks on targets in northern Iraq to pursue their own Kurdish rebels.
The US-led air force in southern Turkey is protecting the Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by Baghdad troops.
Saudi riyal exchange rates remained stable in calm summer trade.
The spot Saudi riyal against the dollar and riyal interbank deposit rates remained mostly stable in quiet summer trade this week, traders in the kingdom said.
"There was no change in the Saudi riyal exchange rate.
A trader said that the market was very calm due to the summer holiday.
The spot rial settled at 3.7504/06 against the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were 5-1/2, 3/8 per cent, three-month 5-5/8, 1/2 per cent and six-month 5-3/4, 5/8 per cent.
One-year funds were at 6, 5-7/8 per cent.
Israel authorised Arafat's departure for the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel on Thursday gave Palestinian President Yasser Arafat permission to fly over its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the PLO, an adviser to Arafat said.
"The problem is over.
Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters that the President's plane was allowed to pass through Israeli airspace but that the President was not expected to travel to the West Bank before Monday.

Arafat was scheduled to meet with former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday, but the venue was changed to Gaza after Israel refused to authorise flights for the Palestinian leader's helicopters.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by stalling Arafat.
In response, Arafat cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials on civil affairs at the Allenby Bridge crossing between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said that Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday after Israel lifted the ban because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat will meet Peres in Gaza after the flight ban.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after the Palestinians said the right-wing Israeli government had prevented the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank to meet the former prime minister.

Japanese Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said at a press conference on Wednesday that he believes the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy to ensure economic growth remains unchanged following the release of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
